{{Infobox comedian |name =Rodney Carrington |image = |imagesize = |caption = |pseudonym = |birth_name =Rodney Scott Carrington {{cite web| url= http://superbhub.com/biography/rodney-carringtons-net-worth-album-divorce/|work=SuperbHub.com| title= Rodney Carrington’s Net Worth, Albums, Divorced, Appearances| accessdate=February 12, 2018}} |birth_date ={{birth date and age|1968|10|19}} |birth_place =[[Longview, Texas|Longview]], Texas{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p294525/biography|pure_url=yes}}|title=Rodney Carrington biography|last=Ankeny|first=Jason|work=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=2009-07-07}} |medium =[[Stand-up comedy|Stand-Up]], [[television]], [[radio]] |nationality =[[United States of America|American]] |active =1998–present |genre = [[Country music|Country]], [[comedy music|comedy]] |subject = |influences = |influenced = |spouse = |signature = |website = [http://rodneycarrington.com rodneycarrington.com] |footnotes = }} '''Rodney Scott Carrington''' (born October 19, 1968) is an American stand-up comedian, actor, and [[country music]] artist. He has released six major-label studio albums and a greatest-hits package, on [[Mercury Records]] and [[Capitol Records]]. His comedy act typically combines stand-up comedy and original songs. Carrington has also starred in the sitcom ''[[Rodney (TV series)|Rodney]]'' and in the 2008 film ''[[Beer for My Horses (film)|Beer for My Horses]]'' ==Early life== Rodney Carrington lived in Longview, Texas from 1968 to 1990.{{cite press release|url=http://www.kilgore.edu/contentdetail.asp?ContentID=330|title=ABC star Rodney Carrington to address KC students|publisher=[[Kilgore College]]|access-date=December 19, 2008|dead-url=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100527231620/http://www.kilgore.edu/contentdetail.asp?ContentID=330|archive-date=May 27, 2010}} He worked as a comedian in local venues, gaining exposure through radio programs such as ''[[The Bob and Tom Show]]''. ==Career== Carrington's first album, ''Hangin' with Rodney'', was released in 1998 via [[Mercury Records Nashville]]. This album, composed of both standup comedy and original songs, contained the non-charting single "Letter to My Penis" and peaked at No. 73 on [[Top Country Albums]]. He moved to [[Capitol Nashville]] for his next album, 2000's ''Morning Wood''. It was his first Top 20 album, and it brought him to the singles charts for the first time with "More of a Man", which reached No. 71 on Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now [[Hot Country Songs]]). After it came the live album ''Live: C'mon Laugh You Bastards'', which did not chart. Carrington's third release for Capitol was 2003's ''Nut Sack''. It included the single "Don't Look Now" which reached No. 60. A ''Greatest Hits'' package followed in 2004. This album comprised selections from his Capitol recordings on two discs: stand-up routines on one disc, and songs on the other. It also included his first non-comedy song, "Things We Didn't Know." Also in 2004, Carrington made his acting debut in ''[[Rodney (TV series)|Rodney]]'', a [[sitcom]] based largely on his own life which aired on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] for two seasons. He released ''King of the Mountains'' in 2007, and in 2008 he appeared in the film ''[[Beer for My Horses (film)|Beer for My Horses]]''. ''King of the Mountains'' contains his second serious song, "Angel Friend", a tribute to his best friend Barry Martin, who died suddenly in 2003. ''El Niño Loco'', his sixth Capitol album, was released in 2009. The latter album is composed entirely of songs, a first for Carrington. And it also contains his 3rd non-comedy song "Funny Man". Later in 2009, Carrington released his first Christmas album, ''Make It Christmas''. The first single from the album, "Camouflage and Christmas Lights" became his first Top 40 country hit in December 2009.{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/people/2007-09-24-rodney-carrington-Q&A_N.htm?loc=interstitialskip | work=USA Today | title=Services}} ==Personal life== Carrington has a home in south [[Tulsa, Oklahoma|Tulsa]] a mile away from [[Bixby, Oklahoma]], a Tulsa suburb, where his [[Rodney (TV series)|2004–2006 sitcom]] was set.John Crook, [http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2004-09-19/entertainment/0409250018_1_rodney-carrington-urban-sitcoms-living "'Rodney' has heartland appeal"], ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'', September 19, 2004. He was previously married to Teri and has three sons with her. ==Concert Tour== *(2016) [[Here Comes The Truth Tour]] ==Discography== ===Studio albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:18em;"| Title ! rowspan="2" style="width:18em;"| Album details ! colspan="5"| Peak chart positions ! rowspan="2" style="width:8em;"| [[Music recording sales certification|Certifications]]
and sales |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! width="45"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]]
